text:
- Now, generative AI can help
automate internal processes
and activities that employees manage daily
to keep their organizations running.
Now, some of these challenges

move way beyond the
jobs to be done category
into a class that I call business systems,

systems that don't just
perform one particular task,

but an ongoing operational
engine for the business,
whether it's hospital procurement

or you're doing work
with account executives
inside advertising businesses,
or you have work with property managers

looking at how to manage
their housing inventory
and repairs and the need for rentals.
The list goes on and on.
Now, these processes are time-consuming
and often today they are managed
through docs and spreadsheets.
So many docs and spreadsheets.
And these are really error-prone.

They are difficult to
maintain, they are insecure,

they are tough to scale
across multiple uses.
And even though there's an opportunity
to automate some of these,
there's quite a high investment required

for software developers to
come in and build applications.
Now, sometimes customers overcome that

by turning to low-code
and no-code capabilities,

being able to try and
create these applications.

But sometimes those
low-code, no-code services
sit outside of the operational domain

and the perimeter that
central IT want to maintain.
And we took a hard look at this
and we started to ask the question,

instead of having to build
these shadow IT systems

or manage with a set of
documents and spreadsheets,
could we turn this whole thing on its head

and instead replace all of
that with a single prompt?

For example, the ability
to be able to create an app
for tracking inventory across stores.
And so today, for the first time,

I'm excited to announce an
entirely new service from AWS
that we call AWS App Studio,

which is the fastest and easiest
way to build applications.

Now, AWS App Studio is
a generative AI-powered
low-code application building service

that makes it easy for
technical professionals
without software development skills
like IT project managers, data engineers,

and enterprise architects
to build secure applications

that solve business problems
in as little as a few minutes.
You can build applications in minutes

with a generative
AI-powered low-code service.

You can deploy highly
scalable applications

that were built according
to AWS best practices
and are fully managed by AWS.
And it also gives central IT visibility
into which applications are created
and provides the ability
to be able to set security guardrails
to safely manage user and data access.
It's free to build an application
and you only pay for what you use
and you're able to save up to 80%
compared to comparable offerings.

So let's see what it's like to
build an app with App Studio
using an expense approval scenario
in just three simple steps.

In App Studio, we can use
natural language to describe
what the application should do,
what kind of data it should handle,
and any actions it needs to perform.
In this example, we'll ask an application

that manages employee
expenses and enables managers

and the finance team to
review them for approval.
Every time the expense status change,

the system will use Slack
to send a notification.
So we can create an app with a prompt.

App Studio uses our prompt
to come up with an overview
that explain what assets it will create,

including the data objects and
the user interface elements.

And we can iterate over
the implementation plan
to provide further instructions.

And once we're happy
with our proposed plan,
we can just click the generate app button,

which will execute the plan
and create our application.
Step two is editing your app.

You can preview your application
along with the sample data

created by App Studio before
switching to the visual builder

where we can edit the user
interface, the data objects,
and the automation actions

that define how the application
should look and behave.
Adding new elements and building new pages

is as easy as dragging
and dropping components
to the desired location on our pages.

And all of these changes
are automatically applied
to your work in progress app
without ever having to leave App Studio

and you can preview
those apps at any time.

Now, we want our
application to notify users
when an expense status changes.
App Studio integrates seamlessly with AWS
and third party services using connectors.
So we can drag and drop the Slack action
to the existing automation workflow.

So every time someone
approves or denies an expense,
it will notify everybody involved.

And with all the UI and
configuration changes in place,

I can now deploy my application
to the test environment

so my team can test it before
pushing it to production
and making it available to everyone.

App Studio makes it
extremely easy to publish
and share applications.

A new version's published
every time the app is updated,

making it really easy to roll
back if you have any issues.
And that's it.
My app is live internally,

secure, scalable,
shareable, and ready to use.

Expenses are filed,
notifications are sent,
and we're good to go.
So that's the AWS App Studio

and I extremely excited to
see how it enables builders
to be able to move more quickly on AWS.
